page.title: Welcome
page.content:
Welcome to the QuickStart guide!

This guide will introduce the core aspects of the Dissolve GUI, and cover the steps required to set up and run a simple simulation.

To quit this guide at any point use the red close button at the top right (this will leave the simulation available for examination) or use File→Close (in which case everything will be closed, and you will return to Dissolve's start page).

page.title: Overview
page.content:
The Dissolve GUI can be used to set up, monitor, and run simulations...

Creating a simulation can be done from scratch, adding the necessary components of the simulation individually, or by using the Setup Wizard (File→Setup Wizard) which can help to construct common types of simulation (which can then be further modified as necessary).

Monitoring a simulation involves plotting data of interest, checking on the progression of the simulation etc., and can be done for both locally- and remotely-running simulations (e.g. those on an HPC machine).

Running simulations from within the GUI is also possible, but Dissolve cannot run in parallel in such cases as the GUI is strictly a serial code.

page.content: The standard view in the Dissolve GUI is composed of three main parts...

The controls header allow the current simulation to be run or stepped (provided it is not running elsewhere) or the state of the current simulation reloaded (if data already exists for it, or it is running elsewhere).

page.title: The GUI - Tabs
page.content: Tabs display all of the available Species and Configurations in the simulation, as well as lists of processing Modules and the underlying Forcefield. The only tab which is always present (and which is the only one visible right now) is the Forcefield tab - all others depend on the content of the simulation.

page.title: The GUI - Messages
page.content: The messages view displays any output from Dissolve or the GUI when creating or running a simulation. It is the first place to look for errors (when something doesn't do as you expect it to).

page.title: Basics - AtomTypes
page.content:
We'll now cover the basic components of a simulation within Dissolve, and on which tabs they are located.

AtomTypes define interatomic interaction parameters between atoms - e.g. Lennard-Jones terms and, optionally, charges - and are used to generate the complete set of pair potentials used to describe interatomic interactions between Species.

All defined AtomTypes for the current simulation can be found on the Forcefield tab.

page.title: Basics - Species
page.content:
Species represent molecules, single atoms, or other useful assemblies of atoms. They define the starting coordinates and any necessary intramolecular terms between the atoms (e.g. chemical bonds or angles), as well as assign AtomTypes to each individual atom. Species also contain isotopologue definitions which describe any required isotopic variants.

Each Species in the simulaton has its own tab which containis all of its relevant definitions. When more than one Species is present, their order is not important.

page.title: Basics - Configurations
page.content:
Configurations are collections of atoms that represent a target system to be studied, be it a bulk liquid, a crystal, or something else. They are constructed from (copies of) one or more Species definitions, in some number and relative proportion, and are typically contained within a box employng period boundary conditions. Configurations are the principal targets of Modules.

Each Configuration has its own tab which, aside from containing a blueprint for its inital construction, also allows quick visualisation of the current coordinates, and (optionally) editing of local processing Modules.

page.title: Basics - Modules
page.content:
Modules perform all of Dissolve's 'interesting' functionality, and usually target one or more Configurations. For instance, there are Modules to evolve the atomic coordinates within Configurations (e.g. AtomShake, MolShake, and MD) and calculate basic correlation functions (e.g. RDF and NeutronSQ). A sequence of Modules makes up the core simulation that Dissolve is to perform, with the exact Modules employed depending on the nature of the system and the purpose of the simulation.

Modules exist in sequence in a processing list, and there can be more than one processing list in a simulation, with each having its own tab. So, for example, a sequence of Modules that evolve the Configurations in a simulation can be kept separate from a sequence of Modules that calculate properties of interest.

page.title: Example - Liquid Argon
page.content:
We'll now set up a simple simulation completely by hand to illustrate the basic usage of the GUI, and discuss a few topics in a bit more detail.

Our target will be to describe liquid argon at 85 K, beginning from a set of reference Lennard-Jones parameters, and then to refine this potential against some experimentally-measured data. Our steps will be:

1) Create a Species to represent an argon atom

2) Add suitable AtomType parameters for interactions between argon atoms

3) Define a Configuration consistent with the experimentally-measured data

4) Create a sequence of processing Modules to evolve the Configuration and refine the interatomic potential

Let's begin!

page.title: Create a Species
page.content:
We need a suitable atomic Species to represent the argon atom in our simulation. You can set one up quickly, including an associated AtomType, by using the Add Species wizard on the Simulation menu (Simulation→Add Species) and following the steps below.

1) In the Add Species wizard, choose Create a Species with a single atom.

2) Choose Ar from the periodic table. The Create associated AtomType is already ticked, and will add a new AtomType for us, so press Next to continue.

3) The name of the new Species can be left as 'Ar'. Choose Finish to complete the wizard.

As you will see, we now have a new tab containing our atomic argon Species, with a single atom located at (0,0,0), and assigned to the AtomType 'Ar', which we will adjust in the next step.

page.title: Set Up the AtomType
page.content:
Go back to the forcefield tab and you will see the new AtomType - this is the sole component of the forcefield in this simulation. Note that all AtomTypes are strictly associated with with one chemical element, and can only be applied to that element.

Our new AtomType exists, but has no useful parameters associated to it (they are all zero) so we must add these in now. For a Lennard-Jones interaction Parameter1 is epsilon (the well depth) in kj/mol while Parameter2 is sigma (which helps define the extent of the repulsive core of the atom) in Angstroms. Enter the following values:

Parameter1 (epsilon) = 0.979

Parameter2 (sigma) = 3.401

These values are taken from Jorgensen's OPLS-AA forcefield.
